answers.answer: Hi!If you have ALS and it is progressing then yes, you can have problem with breathing. Breathlessness can be due to several causes. The commonest cause is anemia. It can also be due to asthma like conditions, bronchitis, high blood pressure, diabetes, hypothyroidism or obesity. Certain heart conditions too can cause breathlessness like mitral valve prolapse, high pulmonary artery pressure etc. Stress and anxiety too can be a cause and so also gastric reflux. What is important is to find out whether you are breathless all the time or is it due to exertion. At times certain triggers can cause breathlessness like a visit to a dusty area, using the blower of a vacuum cleaner, visit to a garden with flowers, perfumes, sprays etc. This is a type of allergic asthma and avoiding allergens will help take care. The best thing would be to consult a general practitioner or PCP and try and assess what is the cause of your problem. Then proper referral for concerned specialist can take things further and get you proper treatment. Take care!

question: I've been having tests for ALS done I'm still looking for a MD in Honolulu who will take my type of medicaid insurance, however, this is the question, lately I've been having some problems breathing.  I find myself out of breath by doing hardly anything at all, like getting into bed, and of coarse things that take more energy then that.  This is the thing, I'm in bed out of breath and I can hear my heart in my ears, feel the pulse in my head, and my whole body is pulsing, my legs, feet, arms, hands.  At the same time I have to tell myself to breath.Do other ALS patients have the same problems?
title: breath of life
